title: Developer Notes
text: Implementing new independence test follows pattern implementing new score. score registration documented . adding new score, must registered three places engine-specific R6 class: Public field score Add score name visible users. set_score() method Add new case maps score name corresponding private method. ... argument set_score() Document validate additional parameters accepted score. set_score() method, add entry form: implement corresponding private method:
code: "my_score" = {   private$my_score(..., use_for_mc = mc) } private$my_score <- function(...) {   # score-specific setup }

title: Developer Notes
text: R6 classes, use PascalCase class names, following conventions used mlr3. Public methods fields use snake_case Private methods fields use snake_case R6 class names nouns (e.g., TetradSearch) distinction helps visually separate classes functions emphasizes R6 classes represent entities rather actions.

title: Developer Notes

See, example, BnlearnSearch, approach implemented.

title: Causal Discovery
text: Suppose DAG: define layout use plotting graphs vignette:  can create data linear Gaussian model corresponding DAG using generate_dag_data(). generate 10000 samples fixed random seed DAG : R code used generate data stored attribute data frame: goal now recover causal structure data alone. use PC algorithm learn causal structure. One key assumptions causal sufficiency, meaning unobserved confounders. can use PC algorithm “tetrad”, “pcalg”, “bnlearn” engines learn structure data. motivation multiple engines may implement different algorithms, tests, scoring methods, algorithm may implemented differently across engines. , set PC algorithm using Fisher’s Z test, significance level 0.05, pcalg engine. , first define PC method using pc() function, pass disco() function along data. can visualize results using plot() function, explicitly provide layout defined graphs easier compare.  PC algorithm recovers correct causal structure Markov equivalence, represented CPDAG. CPDAG represents equivalence class DAGs encode conditional independencies. first notable feature plot edges directed, others undirected. example, edge X1 Y directed, indicating causal effect X1 Y, reverse direction. contrast, edge X2 X3 undirected, indicating data alone provide sufficient information determine causal direction. orientations X2 %-->% X3 X3 %-->% X2 compatible observed conditional independencies. demonstrate non-identifiability causal direction X2 X3 reversing direction edge data-generating process applying PC algorithm resulting data set.  learn causal structure , demonstrating direction influence X2 X3 determined data alone.
code: cg <- caugi::caugi(     Z %-->% X1,     X3 %-->% X2,     X1 %-->% Y,     X2 %-->% Y ) layout <- caugi::caugi_layout_sugiyama(cg) plot(cg, layout = layout, main = "True DAG") data_linear <- generate_dag_data(   cg,   n = 10000,   seed = 1405 ) head(data_linear) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>        Z      X3     X1      X2       Y #>    <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1  0.632  0.297   0.773 -0.256  -0.730  #> 2 -1.67  -1.10   -1.20   1.10   -0.722  #> 3 -0.214  0.713   1.09   0.0264  0.261  #> 4 -1.61  -0.171  -1.21  -0.0346  0.0746 #> 5  1.57   0.0517  0.402 -0.874   1.40   #> 6 -1.08   0.178  -1.09   0.189   0.0591 attr(data_linear, "generating_model") #> $dgp #> $dgp$X3 #> rnorm(n, sd = 0.95) #>  #> $dgp$X2 #> X3 * 0.159 + rnorm(n, sd = 0.507) #>  #> $dgp$Z #> rnorm(n, sd = 1.794) #>  #> $dgp$X1 #> Z * 0.3 + rnorm(n, sd = 1.634) #>  #> $dgp$Y #> X1 * 0.61 + X2 * 0.31 + rnorm(n, sd = 1.216) pc_pcalg <- pc(engine = "pcalg", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) pc_result_pcalg <- disco(data = data_linear, method = pc_pcalg) plot(pc_result_pcalg, layout = layout, main = "PC (pcalg)") cg_reverse <- caugi::caugi(   Z %-->% X1,   X2 %-->% X3,   X1 %-->% Y,   X2 %-->% Y )  data_linear_reverse <- generate_dag_data(   cg_reverse,   n = 10000,   seed = 1405 )  pc_result_reverse <- disco(data = data_linear_reverse, method = pc_pcalg) plot(pc_result_reverse, layout = layout, main = "PC (pcalg) reversed")

title: Causal Discovery
text: practice, unobserved confounders may present, violating assumptions PC algorithm. Suppose following DAG unobserved confounder U X1 X2: can visualize DAG, marking unobserved variable U red using dashed edges indicate unobserved:  can generate data DAG using generate_dag_data(), afterwards remove unobserved variable U data frame: can apply PC algorithm :  see PC algorithm recover correct causal structure due presence unobserved confounder. particular, found incorrect edge X1 X2.
code: cg_unobserved <- caugi::caugi(   Z %-->% X1,   X3 %-->% X2,   X1 %-->% Y,   X2 %-->% Y,   U %-->% X1 + X2 ) plot(   cg_unobserved,   edge_style = list(     by_edge = list(       U = list(col = "red", fill = "red", lty = "dashed")     )   ),   node_style = list(     by_node = list(       U = list(col = "red", fill = "red")     )   ),   main = "True DAG with unobserved confounder" ) data_unobserved <- generate_dag_data(   cg_unobserved,   n = 10000,   seed = 1405 ) data_unobserved <- data_unobserved[, names(data_unobserved) != "U"] head(data_unobserved) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>         Z      X3     X1     X2       Y #>     <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1  0.608   1.42   -1.31  -1.69   1.99   #> 2 -0.716  -0.357  -0.490 -0.561  0.955  #> 3  1.22    1.49   -0.124 -1.48   1.52   #> 4 -0.752  -0.188   0.877  1.35  -1.39   #> 5 -0.0863  0.0156  1.54  -0.926 -0.0833 #> 6 -0.799  -0.929   0.802  0.253 -0.939 pc_pcalg_unobserved <- pc(engine = "pcalg", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) pc_result_unobserved <- disco(data = data_unobserved, method = pc_pcalg_unobserved) plot(pc_result_unobserved, layout = layout, main = "PC (pcalg) unobserved confounder")

title: causalDisco
text: section use num_data dataset included package demonstrating run causal discovery algorithms. contains 5 numerical variables, X1, X2, X3, Z, Y. make different causal graphs easier interpret, define custom fixed layout plotting results: run causal discovery algorithm, first define algorithm using corresponding function, pass disco() function along data. demonstrate process using Peter-Clark (PC) algorithm bnlearn Fisher’s Z test: can visualize results using plot():  first notable feature plot edges directed, others undirected. example, edge X1 Y directed, indicating causal effect X1 Y. contrast, edge X1 X3 undirected, indicating data alone provide sufficient information determine causal direction. orientations X1 %-->% X3 X3 %-->% X1 compatible observed conditional independencies. view engines available specific algorithm, can see documentation using ?pc, options listed engine argument. Instead using bnlearn, can also use PC implementation pcalg package test:  see results using PC algorithm implemented bnlearn pcalg gives output dataset. can also use different algorithm altogether, GES algorithm. follows pattern, however GES score-based algorithm, instead test alpha level, need specify score. use Extended Bayesian Information Criterion (EBIC) score Tetrad. Tetrad written Java, use first need ensure Java installed Tetrad jar files available. can done using check_tetrad_install() function. aren’t installed, provide helper functions install_java() install_tetrad() set .  want customize plot appearance , can pass additional arguments plot(). example, change appearance nodes, can use node_style argument:  details customizing plots generating TikZ code LaTeX documents, see visualization vignette. Instead using plot(), another way view analyze results use print() summary() functions:
code: data(num_data) head(num_data) #>         X1        X2       X3         Z        Y #> 1 3.900715  7.048325 6.964806 10.272479 15.35505 #> 2 4.736112  6.236746 5.666022 10.357262 23.36749 #> 3 4.657992 12.169805 9.127046  9.138338 25.32495 #> 4 5.176469  6.392344 6.101088 10.808335 26.75643 #> 5 4.535538 10.305236 7.465185 10.612735 22.67612 #> 6 4.885914 10.018856 7.413312  9.375931 28.03132 plot_layout <- data.frame(   name = c("Z", "X3", "X1", "X2", "Y"),   x = c(0.00, 0.50, 0.00, 0.50, 0.25),   y = c(0.0, 0.0, 0.5, 0.5, 1.0) ) pc_bnlearn <- pc(   engine = "bnlearn", # Use the bnlearn implementation   test = "fisher_z", # Use Fisher's Z test for conditional independence   alpha = 0.05 # Significance level for the test ) pc_result_bnlearn <- disco(data = num_data, method = pc_bnlearn) plot(pc_result_bnlearn, layout = plot_layout, main = "PC Fisher Z (bnlearn)") pc_pcalg <- pc(   engine = "pcalg", # Use the pcalg implementation   test = "fisher_z", # Use Fisher's Z test for conditional independence   alpha = 0.05 # Significance level for the test ) pc_result_pcalg <- disco(data = num_data, method = pc_pcalg) plot(pc_result_pcalg, layout = plot_layout, main = "PC Fisher Z (pcalg)") if (check_tetrad_install()$installed && check_tetrad_install()$java_ok) {   ges_tetrad <- ges(     engine = "tetrad", # Use the Tetrad implementation     score = "ebic" # Use the EBIC score   )   ges_result_tetrad <- disco(data = num_data, method = ges_tetrad)   plot(ges_result_tetrad, layout = plot_layout, main = "GES EBIC (Tetrad)") } plot(   pc_result_bnlearn,   layout = plot_layout,   main = "Customized plot",   node_style = list(     fill = "lightblue", # Fill color     col = "darkblue", # Border color     lwd = 2, # Border width     padding = 4, # Text padding (mm)     size = 1.2 # Size multiplier   ) ) print(pc_result_bnlearn) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X1    ---   Z     #> 3 X2    ---   X3    #> 4 X2    -->   Y     #> 5 X3    -->   Y     #> 6 Z     -->   Y #> ── Nodes ── #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── summary(pc_result_bnlearn) #>  #> ── caugi graph summary ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #> Nodes: 5 #> Edges: 6 #>  #> ── Knowledge summary ── #>  #> Tiers: 0 #> Variables: 0 #> Required edges: 0 #> Forbidden edges: 0 #>  #> ── Variables per Tier

title: causalDisco
text: section use dataset tpc_example, contains variables, measured three different life stages: childhood, youth, old age. Since know temporal ordering variables, can incorporate background knowledge causal discovery algorithm. Specifically, know variables measured childhood caused variables measured youth old age, variables measured youth caused variables measured old age. Knowledge encoded creating knowledge object via knowledge() function. first argument (optional, recommended name matching) specifies dataset. Tiered knowledge can defined using tier() function. , illustrate creating tiered knowledge structure based life stages: details define knowledge, see knowledge vignette. can view knowledge object using print(), summary() plot():  plot displays vertical tiers, enclosed shaded rectangle labeled corresponding tier name top. can incorporate knowledge algorithm like . , need pass knowledge object argument disco() function. use Temporal Peter-Clark (tpc) algorithm causalDisco regression-based information loss test: Similarly, can view results using print(), summary() plot():  Like , tiered knowledge reflected plot layout, variables grouped life stage. Additionally, can customize plot appearance passing additional arguments plot().
code: data(tpc_example) head(tpc_example) #>   child_x2   child_x1    youth_x4 youth_x3  oldage_x6  oldage_x5 #> 1        0 -0.7104066 -0.07355602        1  6.4984994  3.0740123 #> 2        0  0.2568837 -1.16865142        1  0.3254685  1.9726530 #> 3        0 -0.2466919 -0.63474826        1  4.1298927  1.9666697 #> 4        1  1.6524574  0.97115845        0 -7.9064009 -4.5160676 #> 5        0 -0.9516186  0.67069597        0  1.7089134  0.7903853 #> 6        1  1.9549723 -0.65054654        0 -6.9758928 -3.2107342 kn <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ c("child_x1", "child_x2"),     youth ~ starts_with("youth"), # tidyselect helper; equivalent to c("youth_x3", "youth_x4")     oldage ~ starts_with("oldage")   ) ) print(kn) #>  #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Tiers ── #>  #>   tier   #>   <chr>  #> 1 child  #> 2 youth  #> 3 oldage #> ── Variables ── #>   var       tier   #>   <chr>     <chr>  #> 1 child_x1  child  #> 2 child_x2  child  #> 3 youth_x3  youth  #> 4 youth_x4  youth  #> 5 oldage_x5 oldage #> 6 oldage_x6 oldage summary(kn) #> ── Knowledge summary ── #> Tiers: 3 #> Variables: 6 #> Required edges: 0 #> Forbidden edges: 0 #>  #> ── Variables per Tier #> child: 2 variables #> oldage: 2 variables #> youth: 2 variables plot(kn, main = "Temporal Knowledge") tpc_method <- tpc(   engine = "causalDisco", # Use the causalDisco implementation   test = "reg" # Use the regression-based information loss test ) tpc_result <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = tpc_method, knowledge = kn) print(tpc_result) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from      edge  to        #>   <chr>     <chr> <chr>     #> 1 child_x1  -->   child_x2  #> 2 child_x2  -->   oldage_x5 #> 3 child_x2  -->   youth_x4  #> 4 oldage_x5 ---   oldage_x6 #> 5 youth_x3  -->   oldage_x5 #> 6 youth_x4  -->   oldage_x6 #> ── Nodes ── #>   name      #>   <chr>     #> 1 child_x2  #> 2 child_x1  #> 3 youth_x4  #> 4 youth_x3  #> 5 oldage_x6 #> 6 oldage_x5 #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ── Tiers ── #>  #>   tier   #>   <chr>  #> 1 child  #> 2 youth  #> 3 oldage #> ── Variables ── #>   var       tier   #>   <chr>     <chr>  #> 1 child_x1  child  #> 2 child_x2  child  #> 3 youth_x3  youth  #> 4 youth_x4  youth  #> 5 oldage_x5 oldage #> 6 oldage_x6 oldage summary(tpc_result) #> ── caugi graph summary ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #> Nodes: 6 #> Edges: 6 #>  #> ── Knowledge summary ── #>  #> Tiers: 3 #> Variables: 6 #> Required edges: 0 #> Forbidden edges: 0 #>  #> ── Variables per Tier #> child: 2 variables #> oldage: 2 variables #> youth: 2 variables plot(tpc_result, main = "TPC reg_test with Temporal Knowledge (causalDisco)")

title: causalDisco
text: information incorporate knowledge, see knowledge vignette. information causal discovery, see causal discovery vignette. information visualization options, see visualization vignette.

title: Knowledge
text: basic level, prior knowledge expressed required forbidden edges variables. constraints apply directed edges causal graph. Required edges specify directed edge must exist two variables. Forbidden edges specify directed edge allowed two variables. constraints specified using %-->% (required) %!-->% (forbidden) operators, exclamation mark (!) indicating negation edge, .e. absence edge. Conceptually, written %!(-->)%, find syntax verbose.

title: Knowledge
text: Suppose want require edge B, C, forbid edge B C: knowledge object can visualized:  blue edge represents required edge B, red edge represents forbidden edge B C. one wishes remove edges (either required forbidden) knowledge existing knowledge object, remove_edge() function can used. example, remove required edge B:
code: kn_1 <- knowledge(   A %-->% c(B, C), # Require edges from A to B and A to C   B %!-->% C # Forbid edge from B to C ) plot(kn_1) kn_1_removed <- remove_edge(kn_1, from = A, to = B) plot(kn_1_removed)

what: Specifying required and forbidden edges in a dataset
title: Knowledge
text: use tpc_example dataset causalDisco package following examples: can pass dataset knowledge first argument, also checks specified variables exist dataset: knowledge object can also visualized (manually adjust layout better appearance):  plot plots variables dataset, required edges blue edges forbidden edges red edges.
code: data(tpc_example) head(tpc_example) #>   child_x2   child_x1    youth_x4 youth_x3  oldage_x6  oldage_x5 #> 1        0 -0.7104066 -0.07355602        1  6.4984994  3.0740123 #> 2        0  0.2568837 -1.16865142        1  0.3254685  1.9726530 #> 3        0 -0.2466919 -0.63474826        1  4.1298927  1.9666697 #> 4        1  1.6524574  0.97115845        0 -7.9064009 -4.5160676 #> 5        0 -0.9516186  0.67069597        0  1.7089134  0.7903853 #> 6        1  1.9549723 -0.65054654        0 -6.9758928 -3.2107342 kn_2 <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   child_x1 %-->% youth_x3, # Require edge from child_x1 to youth_x3   child_x2 %!-->% oldage_x5 # Forbid edge from child_x2 to oldage_x5 ) cg <- knowledge_to_caugi(kn_2)$caugi layout <- caugi::caugi_layout_sugiyama(cg) layout[6, 2] <- layout[4, 2]  plot(kn_2, layout = layout)

previous_headings: Required and forbidden knowledge > Specifying required and forbidden edges in a dataset
title: Knowledge
text: make specifying variables easier, can use tidyselect helpers starts_with: means, variables starting “child” required edges variables starting “youth”, variables starting “oldage” can edges variables starting “youth”. can visualize :  list available tidyselect helpers refer tidyselect reference documentation.
code: kn_3 <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   starts_with("child") %-->% starts_with("youth"),   starts_with("oldage") %!-->% starts_with("youth") ) plot(kn_3)

title: Knowledge
text: Tiered knowledge provides higher-level abstraction expressing systematic ordering assumptions, temporal logical precedence. Internally, tiered knowledge translated collection forbidden edges, exposed separately provides concise structured way express common ordering assumptions. example, consider dataset three groups variables: child, youth, old. may wish enforce child variables precede youth variables, turn precede old variables. can expressed using tiered knowledge. Tiered knowledge enforces edges may point earlier tiers later tiers. Edges within tier unrestricted unless additional knowledge supplied.

title: Knowledge
text: Suppose observe variables time: first ’s, B’s, finally C’s. ordering implies causal direction go backward time (e.g., B’s cause ’s). tiered knowledge object captures temporal structure specifying tiers associated variables. numeric tiers used, lower numbers indicate earlier tiers; otherwise, tiers ordered appearance. following specifications encode tier structure: can visualize tiers:  plot shows tiers layers, earliest tiers left latest right. can convert meaning tiered knowledge explicit forbidden edges using convert_tiers_to_forbidden():  Tidyselect helpers starts_with can also used define tiers concise way, just required forbidden edges. Different tidyselect helpers can freely combined within tier definition using +. example, following tiered knowledge object defines two tiers, “young” “old”, combining tidyselect helpers:
code: kn <- knowledge(   tier(     1 ~ c(A1, A2),     2 ~ c(B1, B2),     3 ~ c(C1, C2)   ) )  # Same object, since tiers are ordered numerically kn_same <- knowledge(   tier(     1 ~ c(A1, A2),     3 ~ c(C1, C2),     2 ~ c(B1, B2)   ) )  # Functionally equivalent, though not identical kn_almost <- knowledge(   tier(     10 ~ c(A1, A2),     30 ~ c(C1, C2),     20 ~ c(B1, B2)   ) )  # Again functionally equivalent kn_also_almost <- knowledge(   tier(     A ~ c(A1, A2),     B ~ c(B1, B2),     C ~ c(C1, C2)   ) )  # Has a letter, so tiers are ordered by appearance, thus functionally equivalent kn_mixed <- knowledge(   tier(     3   ~ c(A1, A2),     B   ~ c(B1, B2),     1   ~ c(C1, C2)   ) ) plot(kn) kn_converted <- convert_tiers_to_forbidden(kn) print(kn_converted) #>  #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Variables ── #>  #>   var   tier  #>   <chr> <chr> #> 1 A1    NA    #> 2 A2    NA    #> 3 B1    NA    #> 4 B2    NA    #> 5 C1    NA    #> 6 C2    NA #> ── Edges ── #>  ✖  B1 → A1 #>  ✖  B1 → A2 #>  ✖  B2 → A1 #>  ✖  B2 → A2 #>  ✖  C1 → A1 #>  ✖  C1 → A2 #>  ✖  C1 → B1 #>  ✖  C1 → B2 #>  ✖  C2 → A1 #>  ✖  C2 → A2 #>  ✖  C2 → B1 #>  ✖  C2 → B2 plot(kn_converted) kn_tier_tidyselect <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     young ~ starts_with("child") + ends_with(c("3", "4")),     old   ~ starts_with("old")   ) ) plot(kn_tier_tidyselect)

title: Knowledge
text: Exogenous variables incoming edges causal graph. , variables known causes affected variables. Exogenous variables can specified using exogenous() function within knowledge().

title: Knowledge
text: natural usage supply dataset variables checked existence selected correctly: Instead exogenous, can also use shorthand function exo(). knowledge object can visualized:  add child_x1 child_x2 exogenous variables using tidyselect helpers:
code: kn_exo_1 <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   exogenous("child_x1") ) plot(kn_exo_1) kn_exo_2 <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   exo(starts_with("child")) ) plot(kn_exo_2, layout = "bipartite", orientation = "columns")

title: Knowledge
text: Different knowledge types can freely combined single knowledge object. example, can combine tiered knowledge required forbidden edges:
code: kn_combined <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     1 ~ starts_with("child"),     2 ~ starts_with("youth"),     3 ~ starts_with("oldage")   ),   child_x1 %-->% youth_x3,   child_x1 %!-->% child_x2 )  plot(kn_combined)

title: Knowledge
text: prior knowledge specified, can supplied causal discovery algorithms passing knowledge object disco() function via knowledge parameter. example, can use Temporal GES algorithm tges() engine “causalDisco” temporal BIC (“tbic”): causal discovery algorithms respects provided knowledge. can plot resulting causal graph:  black edges inferred data.
code: kn <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     1 ~ starts_with("child"),     2 ~ starts_with("youth"),     3 ~ starts_with("oldage")   ) )  cd_tges <- tges(engine = "causalDisco", score = "tbic") disco_cd_tges <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = cd_tges, knowledge = kn) plot(disco_cd_tges)

title: Knowledge
text: engine mean underlying implementation causal discovery algorithm, .e. engine specify algorithm pc(engine = "bnlearn") tges(engine = "causalDisco").

title: Knowledge
text: knowledge types supported bnlearn engine. required knowledge provided, bnlearn may emit warning structure learning. occurs algorithm identifies candidate v-structure (collider) data whose orientation conflicts edges already oriented due background knowledge. resulting causal graph still respect provided knowledge.
code: data(tpc_example)  kn <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   child_x1 %-->% youth_x3 )  bnlearn_pc <- pc(engine = "bnlearn", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) output <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = bnlearn_pc, knowledge = kn) #> Warning in vstruct.apply(arcs = arcs, vs = vs, nodes = nodes, debug = debug): #> vstructure child_x2 -> oldage_x5 <- youth_x3 is not applicable, because one or #> both arcs are oriented in the opposite direction. plot(output)

title: Knowledge
text: causalDisco engine supports tiered forbidden knowledge. required knowledge provided, give warning ignore required knowledge.

title: Knowledge
text: forbidden symmetric knowledge supported pcalg engine. , edges forbidden directions. Thus, type knowledge can used pcalg knowledge created using forbidden edges (%!-->%) without required tier knowledge. example shown :
code: data(tpc_example) kn <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   child_x1 %!-->% youth_x3,   youth_x3 %!-->% child_x1 ) pc_pcalg <- pc(engine = "pcalg", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) output <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = pc_pcalg, knowledge = kn)

title: Knowledge
text: knowledge types supported Tetrad engine.

title: Extending causalDisco with New Algorithms
text: Suppose want add Hybrid Parents Children (HPC) algorithm bnlearn. can integrate causalDisco creating new function hpc(). HPC constraint-based algorithm, requires conditional independence test significance level alpha. returns PDAG, set graph_class attribute "PDAG". function takes engine argument, specifies implementation algorithm use. Even though add HPC bnlearn example, set structure allow multiple engines future. ... argument allows us pass additional arguments underlying algorithm test. code hpc() function follows: see hpc() function needs two components: Builder function: Constructs runner algorithm. configures algorithm provided parameters optional background knowledge. Method object: Created via new_disco_method(). encapsulates builder metadata method. allows us able call disco() execute algorithm dataset. Next, define runner. runner handles configuring search object chosen test, alpha level, additional arguments, actually runs search data called. bnlearn algorithms, use BnlearnSearch R6 class manage search configuration execution. also use distribute_engine_args() determine extra arguments passed test, algorithm, . defined, HPC algorithm can used like method causalDisco. first construct method using hpc(), pass disco(). demonstrate using included tpc_example dataset:  implement score-based algorithm instead, structure remain . main difference method accept score argument rather test alpha, runner call search$set_score() instead search$set_test(). hybrid algorithm algorithm accept test, alpha, score arguments, runner call set_test() set_score(). implement algorithm pcalg rather bnlearn, follow structure use R6 class PcalgSearch instead BnlearnSearch runner (.e., PcalgSearch$new()).
code: hpc <- function(   engine = c("bnlearn"),   test,   alpha = 0.05,   ... ) {   engine <- match.arg(engine)   args <- rlang::list2(...)    builder <- function(knowledge = NULL) {     runner <- switch(       engine,       bnlearn = rlang::exec(         hpc_bnlearn_runner,         test = test,         alpha = alpha,         !!!args       )     )     runner   }   method <- new_disco_method(     builder = builder,     name = "hpc",     engine = engine,     graph_class = "PDAG"   )   method } hpc_bnlearn_runner <- function(test, alpha, ...) {   args <- list(...)   search <- BnlearnSearch$new()   args_to_pass <- distribute_engine_args(     search = search,     args = args,     engine = "bnlearn",     alg = "hpc"   )    search$set_test(test, alpha)   search$set_alg("hpc", args_to_pass)    runner <- list(     set_knowledge = function(knowledge) {       search$set_knowledge(knowledge)     },     run = function(data) {       search$run_search(data)     }   )   runner } data(tpc_example) hpc_bnlearn <- hpc(engine = "bnlearn", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) hpc_bnlearn_result <- disco(tpc_example, hpc_bnlearn) plot(hpc_bnlearn_result)

title: Extending causalDisco with New Algorithms
text: illustrate make custom version (actually implementation, just defensive programming omitted) Boss algorithm Tetrad. Tetrad algorithms follow slightly different integration pattern Tetrad Java application rather R package. add new Tetrad algorithm, first register register_tetrad_algorithm(). function requires: algorithm name. setup function configures TetradSearch object execute algorithm. setup function receives TetradSearch object first argument, along additional parameters passed via ... method constructed. responsibilities : Configure TetradSearch object appropriate parameters score. Instantiate correct Tetrad algorithm class. fully qualified class name can identified inspecting Tetrad source code : https://github.com/cmu-phil/tetrad sure browse version corresponding installed Tetrad release. relevant Java classes located : https://github.com/cmu-phil/tetrad/tree/development/tetrad-lib/src/main/java can view custom registered Tetrad algorithms using tetrad_alg_registry(), reset using reset_tetrad_alg_registry(). Like bnlearn pcalg, create method function my_boss_variant() constructs builder function turn constructs runner using registered Tetrad algorithm. BOSS score-based algorithm, method accepts score argument passes runner, configures TetradSearch object accordingly. returns PDAG, set graph_class attribute "PDAG". Next define runner function my_boss_variant_tetrad_runner() defined can now run my_boss_variant() like method causalDisco.  , using hybrid constraint-based algorithm rather score-based one, structure remain method accept different arguments (e.g., test alpha constraint-based algorithm).
code: register_tetrad_algorithm(   "my_boss_variant",   function(     self,     num_starts = 1,     use_bes = TRUE,     use_data_order = TRUE,     output_cpdag = TRUE   ) {     self$set_params(       USE_BES = use_bes,       NUM_STARTS = num_starts,       USE_DATA_ORDER = use_data_order,       OUTPUT_CPDAG = output_cpdag     )      self$alg <- rJava::.jnew(       "edu/cmu/tetrad/algcomparison/algorithm/oracle/cpdag/Boss",       self$score     )     self$alg$setKnowledge(self$knowledge)   } ) my_boss_variant <- function(   engine = "tetrad",   score,   ... ) {   engine <- match.arg(engine)   args <- rlang::list2(...)    builder <- function(knowledge = NULL) {     runner <- switch(       engine,       tetrad = rlang::exec(my_boss_variant_tetrad_runner, score, !!!args)     )     runner   }    method <- new_disco_method(     builder = builder,     name = "my_boss_variant",     engine = engine,     graph_class = "PDAG"   )   method } my_boss_variant_tetrad_runner <- function(score, ...) {   search <- TetradSearch$new()   args <- list(...)   args_to_pass <- distribute_engine_args(     search = search,     args = args,     engine = "tetrad",     alg = "my_boss_variant"   )    if (length(args_to_pass$score_args) > 0) {     rlang::exec(search$set_score, score, !!!args_to_pass$score_args)   } else {     search$set_score(score)   }    if (length(args_to_pass$alg_args) > 0) {     rlang::exec(search$set_alg, "my_boss_variant", !!!args_to_pass$alg_args)   } else {     search$set_alg("my_boss_variant")   }    runner <- list(     set_knowledge = function(knowledge) {       search$set_knowledge(knowledge)     },     run = function(data) {       search$run_search(data)     }   )   runner } # Ensure Tetrad is installed and Java is working before running the algorithm if (check_tetrad_install()$installed && check_tetrad_install()$java_ok) {   my_boss_variant_tetrad <- my_boss_variant(engine = "tetrad", score = "sem_bic")   my_boss_variant_tetrad_result <- disco(tpc_example, my_boss_variant_tetrad)   plot(my_boss_variant_tetrad_result) }

title: Visualization
text: can visualize causal graphs using plot() function, works knowledge knowledgeable_caugi objects. function leverages underlying caugi::plot() method, providing flexible options customizing appearance nodes edges.

title: Visualization
text: start creating simple knowledge object visualizing plot(). knowledge encodes following relationships variables dataset:  default, required edges shown blue forbidden edges red. can customize colors using required_col forbidden_col arguments:  Different node layouts, node styles, edge styles can specified using layout, node_style, edge_style parameters. provide quick example refer causalDisco::plot() function (underlying caugi::plot() function) documentation details. use “fruchterman-reingold” layout customize node edge styles:  can also pass custom layout plot():
code: data(num_data) kn <- knowledge(   num_data,   X1 %-->% c(X2, X3), # Require edge from X1 to X2, and X1 to X3   X2 %!-->% c(X3, Y), # Forbid edge from X2 to X3, and X2 to Y   Y %!-->% Z  # Forbid edge from Y to Z )  plot(kn) plot(kn, required_col = "skyblue", forbidden_col = "orange") plot(   kn,   layout = "fruchterman-reingold",   node_style = list(     fill = "lightblue", # Fill color     col = "darkblue", # Border color     lwd = 2, # Border width     padding = 4, # Text padding (mm)     size = 1.2 # Size multiplier   ),   edge_style = list(     lwd = 1.5, # Edge width     arrow_size = 4 # Arrow size (mm)   ) ) my_layout <- data.frame(   name = c("X1", "X2", "X3", "Y", "Z"),   x = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5),   y = c(1, 2, 1, 2, 1) ) plot(kn, layout = my_layout)

title: Visualization
text: can also visualize tiered knowledge structures. example using dataset variables measured different life stages:  Variables grouped life stage, reflecting tiered structure. helps visually convey temporal hierarchical relationships data.
code: data(tpc_example) kn_tiered <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ starts_with("child"), # tidyselect helper; equivalent to c("child_x1", "child_x2")     youth ~ starts_with("youth"),     old ~ starts_with("old")   ),   child_x1 %-->% child_x2,   child_x2 %!-->% youth_x3 ) plot(kn_tiered)

title: Visualization
text: run causal discovery algorithm get knowledgeable_caugi, knowledge object alongside learned causal graph caugi object. can plot combined object see prior knowledge learned relationships  Blue edges indicate required relationships prior knowledge, black edges show learned data, forbidden edges plotted (avoid confusion clutter). tiered knowledge, plotting works similarly:  can see tiers reflected layout graph.
code: data(num_data) kn <- knowledge(   num_data,   X1 %-->% X2,   X2 %!-->% c(X3, Y),   Y %!-->% Z )  pc_bnlearn <- pc(engine = "bnlearn", test = "fisher_z") pc_result <- disco(num_data, method = pc_bnlearn, knowledge = kn) plot(pc_result) data(tpc_example) kn_tiered <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ starts_with("child"),     youth ~ starts_with("youth"),     old ~ starts_with("old")   ) ) cd_tges <- tges(engine = "causalDisco", score = "tbic") disco_cd_tges <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = cd_tges, knowledge = kn_tiered) plot(disco_cd_tges)

title: Visualization
text: make_tikz() function exports plots clean, fully editable TikZ code inclusion LaTeX documents. Unlike graph export tools, edges attached nodes rather positioned using hard-coded coordinates, making output easier modify. functionality works knowledge, knowledgeable_caugi, caugi::caugi objects, allowing customize layouts, styles, edges LaTeX document. calls underlying causalDisco::plot() method (calls caugi::plot()) generate initial plot object converting TikZ code. Thus, can supply arguments make_tikz() supported causalDisco::plot() caugi::plot().

title: Visualization
text: first demonstrate TikZ export knowledge object. Setting full_doc = TRUE generates complete standalone LaTeX document can compiled directly. Using full_doc = FALSE instead returns tikzpicture environment, convenient inclusion inside existing LaTeX document. TikZ export also supports edge bending, can substantially improve readability edges passes thorugh nodes, can easily happen tiered knowledge structures. feature available standard caugi::plot() function. example, edge using standard straight style edge overlaps node youth_x3, bent edge avoids overlap:  TikZ plot can seen :
code:
data(num_data) kn <- knowledge(   num_data,   X1 %-->% X2,   X2 %!-->% c(X3, Y),   Y %!-->% Z )  # Full standalone document tikz_knowledge_code <- make_tikz(kn, scale = 10, full_doc = TRUE) cat(tikz_knowledge_code) #> %%% Generated by causalDisco (version 0.9.5.9048) #> \documentclass[tikz,border=2mm]{standalone} #> \usetikzlibrary{arrows.meta, positioning, shapes.geometric, fit, backgrounds, calc} #>  #>  egin{document} #> 	ikzset{every node/.style={fill=lightgray}, every path/.style={draw=red}} #> 	ikzset{arrows={[scale=3]}, arrow/.style={-{Stealth}, thick}} #>  egin{tikzpicture} #> 
ode[draw, circle] (X1) at (1.667,0) {X1}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (X2) at (1.667,3.333) {X2}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (X3) at (3.333,6.667) {X3}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (Y) at (0,6.667) {Y}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (Z) at (0,10) {Z}; #> \path (X1) edge[draw=blue, -Latex] (X2) #>       (X2) edge[, -Latex] (X3) #>       (X2) edge[, -Latex] (Y) #>       (Y) edge[, -Latex] (Z); #> \end{tikzpicture} #> \end{document}  # Only the tikzpicture environment tikz_knowledge_snippet <- make_tikz(kn, scale = 10, full_doc = FALSE) cat(tikz_knowledge_snippet) #> %%% Generated by causalDisco (version 0.9.5.9048) #> 	ikzset{every node/.style={fill=lightgray}, every path/.style={draw=red}} #> 	ikzset{arrows={[scale=3]}, arrow/.style={-{Stealth}, thick}} #>  egin{tikzpicture} #> 
ode[draw, circle] (X1) at (1.667,0) {X1}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (X2) at (1.667,3.333) {X2}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (X3) at (3.333,6.667) {X3}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (Y) at (0,6.667) {Y}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (Z) at (0,10) {Z}; #> \path (X1) edge[draw=blue, -Latex] (X2) #>       (X2) edge[, -Latex] (X3) #>       (X2) edge[, -Latex] (Y) #>       (Y) edge[, -Latex] (Z); #> \end{tikzpicture} data(tpc_example) kn_tiered <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ starts_with("child"),     youth ~ starts_with("youth"),     old ~ starts_with("old")   ),   child_x1 %-->% oldage_x5 )  plot(kn_tiered) tikz_bent_tiered <- make_tikz(   kn_tiered,   scale = 10,   full_doc = FALSE,   bend_edges = TRUE,   bend_angle = 20 ) cat(tikz_bent_tiered) #> %%% Generated by causalDisco (version 0.9.5.9048) #> 	ikzset{every node/.style={fill=lightgray}, every path/.style={draw=blue}} #> 	ikzset{arrows={[scale=3]}, arrow/.style={-{Stealth}, thick}} #>  egin{tikzpicture} #> 
ode[draw, circle] (child_x1) at (0,0) {child\_x1}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (child_x2) at (0,10) {child\_x2}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (youth_x3) at (5,0) {youth\_x3}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (youth_x4) at (5,10) {youth\_x4}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (oldage_x5) at (10,0) {oldage\_x5}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (oldage_x6) at (10,10) {oldage\_x6}; #>  egin{scope}[on background layer] #> 
ode[draw, rectangle, fill=blue!20, rounded corners, inner sep=0.5cm, fit=(child_x1)(child_x2)] (child) {}; #> 
ode[draw, rectangle, fill=blue!20, rounded corners, inner sep=0.5cm, fit=(oldage_x5)(oldage_x6)] (old) {}; #> 
ode[draw, rectangle, fill=blue!20, rounded corners, inner sep=0.5cm, fit=(youth_x3)(youth_x4)] (youth) {}; #> \end{scope} #> 
ode[anchor=south, draw=none, fill=none] at ($(child.north)+(0cm,0.2cm)$) {child}; #> 
ode[anchor=south, draw=none, fill=none] at ($(old.north)+(0cm,0.2cm)$) {old}; #> 
ode[anchor=south, draw=none, fill=none] at ($(youth.north)+(0cm,0.2cm)$) {youth}; #> \path (child_x1) edge[bend left=20, -Latex] (oldage_x5); #> \end{tikzpicture}

title: Visualization
text: output disco() gives knowledgeable_caugi object, can also exported TikZ:
code:
data(tpc_example) kn_tiered <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ starts_with("child"),     youth ~ starts_with("youth"),     old ~ starts_with("old")   ) )  tiers <- list(   child = c("child_x1", "child_x2"),   youth = c("youth_x3", "youth_x4"),   old = c("oldage_x5", "oldage_x6") )  cd_tges <- tges(engine = "causalDisco", score = "tbic") disco_cd_tges <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = cd_tges, knowledge = kn_tiered)  disco_plot <- plot(disco_cd_tges) tikz_snippet <- make_tikz(disco_plot, tier_node_map = tiers, scale = 10, full_doc = FALSE) cat(tikz_snippet) #> %%% Generated by causalDisco (version 0.9.5.9048) #> 	ikzset{every node/.style={fill=lightgray}} #> 	ikzset{arrows={[scale=3]}, arrow/.style={-{Stealth}, thick}} #>  egin{tikzpicture} #> 
ode[draw, circle] (child_x2) at (0,0) {child\_x2}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (child_x1) at (0,10) {child\_x1}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (youth_x4) at (5,0) {youth\_x4}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (youth_x3) at (5,10) {youth\_x3}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (oldage_x6) at (10,0) {oldage\_x6}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (oldage_x5) at (10,10) {oldage\_x5}; #> \path (child_x1) edge[, -] (child_x2) #>       (child_x2) edge[, -Latex] (oldage_x5) #>       (child_x2) edge[, -Latex] (youth_x4) #>       (oldage_x5) edge[, -Latex] (oldage_x6) #>       (youth_x3) edge[, -Latex] (oldage_x5) #>       (youth_x4) edge[, -Latex] (oldage_x6); #> \end{tikzpicture}

title: Visualization
text: export mechanism also applies standard caugi objects:
code:
cg <- caugi::caugi(   A %-->% B + C ) plot_obj <- caugi::plot(cg, node_style = list(fill = "red")) tikz_caugi_snippet <- make_tikz(plot_obj, scale = 10, full_doc = FALSE) cat(tikz_caugi_snippet) #> %%% Generated by causalDisco (version 0.9.5.9048) #> 	ikzset{every node/.style={fill=red}} #> 	ikzset{arrows={[scale=3]}, arrow/.style={-{Stealth}, thick}} #>  egin{tikzpicture} #> 
ode[draw, circle] (A) at (5,0) {A}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (B) at (10,10) {B}; #> 
ode[draw, circle] (C) at (0,10) {C}; #> \path (A) edge[, -Latex] (B) #>       (A) edge[, -Latex] (C); #> \end{tikzpicture}

what: Do not implement (commented out from doc)
title: Add bnlearn Algorithms
text: Local / skeleton discovery hpc – Hybrid Parents Children mmpc – Max–Min Parents Children si_hiton_pc – Semi-Interleaved HITON-PC since skeleton discovery isn’t useful. Pairwise mutual-information learners aracne – ARACNE network chow_liu – Chow–Liu tree since learn undirected dependency structures based solely pairwise mutual information, rather DAGs CPDAGs, therefore fall outside project’s focus directed graphical model structure learning. Score-based hc - hill-climbing tabu - Tabu search since always returns DAGs (even causal direction possible infer).

what: Maybe add? (commented out from doc for now)

text: Hybrid h2pc – Hybrid HPC–PC mmhc – Max–Min Hill-Climbing rsmax2 – Restricted Maximisation (two-stage)

title: Tools for Causal Discovery on Observational Data
text: Causal discovery methods exist many ecosystems, example bnlearn, pcalg, Tetrad, APIs vary widely. causalDisco unifies one clear grammar, making easy compare results, switch algorithms, focus scientific questions rather package quirks. Time hit disco 🪩

title: Tools for Causal Discovery on Observational Data

title: Tools for Causal Discovery on Observational Data
text: causalDisco depends package caugi, requires Rust installed system. See https://rust-lang.org/tools/install/ instructions install Rust.

title: Tools for Causal Discovery on Observational Data
text: causalDisco provides interface Java library Tetrad causal discovery algorithms. use algorithms Tetrad need install Java Development Kit (JDK) >= 21. recommend Eclipse Temurin (OpenJDK), available https://adoptium.net major operating systems. Alternatively, provide helper function install Temurin JDK 25 macOS Windows: current supported version Tetrad can installed calling verify everything set correctly can run check_tetrad_install():
code: causalDisco::install_java() causalDisco::install_tetrad() causalDisco::check_tetrad_install() #> $installed #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $version #> [1] "7.6.10" #>  #> $java_ok #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $java_version #> [1] "25.0.2" #>  #> $message #> [1] "Tetrad found (version 7.6.10). Java version 25.0.2 is OK."

title: Tools for Causal Discovery on Observational Data
text: causalDisco can currently run causal discovery algorithms package causalDisco , R packages bnlearn pcalg, Java application Tetrad consistent syntax. provide simple example use different backends code structure. also show incorporate tiered background knowledge. can visualize resulting causal graph using plot() function:  Please see package vignettes detailed introductions package features, incorporate knowledge, run causal discovery, visualize results.
code: library(causalDisco) #> causalDisco startup: #>   Java heap size requested: 2 GB #>   Tetrad version: 7.6.10 #>   Java successfully initialized with 2 GB. #>   To change heap size, set options(java.heap.size = 'Ng') or Sys.setenv(JAVA_HEAP_SIZE = 'Ng') *before* loading. #>   Restart R to apply changes.  # Load data data(tpc_example)  pcalg_ges <- ges(   engine = "pcalg", # Use the pcalg implementation   score = "sem_bic" # Use BIC score for model selection ) disco_pcalg_ges <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = pcalg_ges)  # We can also pass background knowledge to the engines that support it. Here we use tiered knowledge, # which is a common way to encode temporal ordering of variables. kn <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ starts_with("child"), # Using the tidyselect syntax to select variables for each tier     youth ~ starts_with("youth"),     old ~ starts_with("old")   ) )  cd_tpc <- tpc(   engine = "causalDisco", # Use the causalDisco implementation   test = "fisher_z", # Use Fisher's Z test for conditional independence   alpha = 0.05 # Significance level for the test ) disco_cd_tpc <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = cd_tpc, knowledge = kn)  bnlearn_pc <- pc(   engine = "bnlearn", # Use the bnlearn implementation   test = "cor", # Use Pearson correlation test for conditional independence   alpha = 0.05 ) disco_bnlearn_pc <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = bnlearn_pc, knowledge = kn)  # Requires Tetrad to be installed if (check_tetrad_install()$installed && check_tetrad_install()$java_ok) {   tetrad_pc <- pc(     engine = "tetrad", # Use the Tetrad implementation     test = "conditional_gaussian", # Use conditional Gaussian test     alpha = 0.05   )   disco_tetrad_pc <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = tetrad_pc, knowledge = kn) } plot(disco_cd_tpc)

what: R6 Interface to bnlearn Search Algorithms — BnlearnSearch
title: R6 Interface to bnlearn Search Algorithms — BnlearnSearch
text: wrapper lets drive bnlearn algorithms within causalDisco framework. arguments test, score, algorithm, see bnlearn documentation.

title: R6 Interface to bnlearn Search Algorithms — BnlearnSearch
text: R6 object methods documented .

title: R6 Interface to bnlearn Search Algorithms — BnlearnSearch
text: data data.frame holding data set currently attached search object. Can set set_data(). score Character scalar naming score function used bnlearn. Can set $set_score(). Kebab-case score names (used bnlearn, e.g. "pred-loglik") also accepted automatically translated snake_case. Recognised values : Continuous - Gaussian "aic_g", "bic_g", "ebic_g", "loglik_g", "pred_loglik_g" - gaussian versions respective scores discrete data. "bge" - Gaussian posterior density. "nal_g" - node-average log-likelihood. "pnal_g" - penalised node-average log-likelihood. Discrete – categorical "aic" - Akaike Information Criterion. "bdla" - locally averaged BDE. "bde" - Bayesian Dirichlet equivalent (uniform). "bds" - Bayesian Dirichlet score. "bic" - Bayesian Information Criterion. "ebic" - Extended BIC. "fnml" - factorised NML. "k2" - K2 score. "loglik" - log-likelihood. "mbde" - modified BDE. "nal" - node-average log-likelihood. "pnal" - penalised node-average log-likelihood. "pred_loglik" - predictive log-likelihood. "qnml" - quotient NML. Mixed Discrete/Gaussian "aic_cg", "bic_cg", "ebic_cg", "loglik_cg", "nal_cg", "pnal_cg", "pred_loglik_cg" - conditional Gaussian versions respective scores discrete data. test Character scalar naming conditional-independence test passed bnlearn. Can set $set_score(). Kebab-case test names (used bnlearn, e.g. "mi-adf") also accepted automatically translated snake_case. Recognised values : Continuous - Gaussian "cor" – Pearson correlation "fisher_z" / "zf" – Fisher Z test "mc_cor" – Monte Carlo Pearson correlation "mc_mi_g" – Monte Carlo mutual information (Gaussian) "mc_zf" – Monte Carlo Fisher Z "mi_g" – mutual information (Gaussian) "mi_g_sh" – mutual information (Gaussian, shrinkage) "smc_cor" – sequential Monte Carlo Pearson correlation "smc_mi_g" – sequential Monte Carlo mutual information (Gaussian) "smc_zf" – sequential Monte Carlo Fisher Z Discrete – categorical "mc_mi" – Monte Carlo mutual information "mc_x2" – Monte Carlo chi-squared "mi" – mutual information "mi_adf" – mutual information adjusted d.f. "mi_sh" – mutual information (shrinkage) "smc_mi" – sequential Monte Carlo mutual information "smc_x2" – sequential Monte Carlo chi-squared "sp_mi" – semi-parametric mutual information "sp_x2" – semi-parametric chi-squared "x2" – chi-squared "x2_adf" – chi-squared adjusted d.f. Discrete – ordered factors "jt" – Jonckheere–Terpstra "mc_jt" – Monte Carlo Jonckheere–Terpstra "smc_jt" – sequential Monte Carlo Jonckheere–Terpstra Mixed Discrete/Gaussian "mi_cg" – mutual information (conditional Gaussian) Monte Carlo tests, set number permutations using B argument. alg Function generated $set_alg() runs structure-learning algorithm bnlearn. Period.case alg names (used bnlearn, e.g. "fast.iamb") also accepted automatically translated snake_case. Recognised values : Constraint-based "fast_iamb" – Fast-IAMB algorithm. See fast_iamb() underlying bnlearn::fast.iamb(). "gs" – Grow-Shrink algorithm. See gs() underlying bnlearn::gs(). "iamb" – Incremental Association Markov Blanket algorithm. See iamb() underlying bnlearn::iamb(). "iamb_fdr" – IAMB FDR control algorithm. See iamb_fdr() underlying bnlearn::iamb.fdr(). "inter_iamb" – Interleaved-IAMB algorithm. See inter_iamb() underlying bnlearn::inter.iamb(). "pc" – PC-stable algorithm. See pc() underlying bnlearn::pc.stable(). params list extra tuning parameters stored set_params() spliced learner call. knowledge list elements whitelist blacklist containing prior-knowledge constraints added via set_knowledge().

code: ### bnlearn_search R6 class examples ###  # Generally, we do not recommend using the R6 classes directly, but rather # use the disco() or any method function, for example pc(), instead.  # Load data data(num_data)  # Recommended: my_pc <- pc(engine = "bnlearn", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) result <- my_pc(num_data)  # or result <- disco(data = num_data, method = my_pc)  plot(result)   # Example with detailed settings: my_pc2 <- pc(   engine = "bnlearn",   test = "mi_g",   alpha = 0.01 ) disco(data = num_data, method = my_pc2) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X1    ---   Z     #> 3 X2    ---   X3    #> 4 X2    -->   Y     #> 5 X3    -->   Y     #> 6 Z     -->   Y     #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # With knowledge  kn <- knowledge(   num_data,   starts_with("X") %-->% Y )  disco(data = num_data, method = my_pc2, knowledge = kn) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X1    ---   Z     #> 3 X2    ---   X3    #> 4 X2    -->   Y     #> 5 X3    -->   Y     #> 6 Z     -->   Y     #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Variables ── #>  #>   var   tier  #>   <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    NA    #> 2 X2    NA    #> 3 X3    NA    #> 4 Y     NA    #> 5 Z     NA    #> ── Edges ── #>  #>  ✔  X1 → Y #>  ✔  X2 → Y #>  ✔  X3 → Y  # Using additional test args (bootstrap samples)  my_iamb <- iamb(   engine = "bnlearn",   test = "mc_zf",   alpha = 0.05,   B = 100 )  disco(data = num_data, method = my_iamb) #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X1    -->   Z     #> 3 X2    ---   X3    #> 4 X2    -->   Y     #> 5 X3    -->   Y     #> 6 Y     -->   Z     #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # Using R6 class: s <- BnlearnSearch$new()  s$set_data(num_data) s$set_test(method = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) s$set_alg("pc")  g <- s$run_search()  plot(g)

what: R6 Interface to causalDisco Search Algorithms — CausalDiscoSearch
title: R6 Interface to causalDisco Search Algorithms — CausalDiscoSearch
text: class implements search algorithms causalDisco package, wraps adds temporal order pcalg algorithms. allows set data, sufficient statistics, test, score, algorithm.

title: R6 Interface to causalDisco Search Algorithms — CausalDiscoSearch
text: data data.frame holding data set currently attached search object. Can set set_data(). score function used build score, data set. Can set $set_score(). Recognized values : "tbic" - Temporal BIC score Gaussian data. See TemporalBIC. "tbdeu" - Temporal BDeu score discrete data. See TemporalBDeu. test function used test independence. Can set $set_test(). Recognized values : "reg" - Regression test discrete binary data. See reg_test(). "fisher_z" - Fisher Z test Gaussian data. See cor_test(). alg function used run search algorithm. Can set $set_alg(). Recognized values : "tfci" - TFCI algorithm. See tfci(). "tges" - TGES algorithm. See tges(). "tpc"  - TPC algorithm. See tpc(). params list parameters test algorithm. Can set $set_params(). TODO: secure yet terms distributing arguments. Use caution. suff_stat Sufficient statistic. format contents sufficient statistic depends test used. knowledge knowledge object holding background knowledge.

title: R6 Interface to causalDisco Search Algorithms — CausalDiscoSearch
code: # Generally, we do not recommend using the R6 classes directly, but rather # use the disco() or any method function, for example pc(), instead.  data(tpc_example)  # background knowledge (tiers + one exogenous var) kn <- knowledge(   tpc_example,   tier(     child ~ starts_with("child"),     youth ~ starts_with("youth"),     old ~ starts_with("oldage")   ) )  # Recommended (TPC example): my_tpc <- tpc(engine = "causalDisco", test = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) result <- disco(data = tpc_example, method = my_tpc, knowledge = kn) plot(result)   # or my_tpc <- my_tpc |>   set_knowledge(kn) result <- my_tpc(tpc_example) plot(result)   # Using R6 class:  # --- Constraint-based: TPC ---------------------------------------------------- s_tpc <- CausalDiscoSearch$new() s_tpc$set_params(list(verbose = FALSE)) s_tpc$set_test("fisher_z", alpha = 0.2) s_tpc$set_alg("tpc") s_tpc$set_knowledge(kn, directed_as_undirected = TRUE) s_tpc$set_data(tpc_example) res_tpc <- s_tpc$run_search() print(res_tpc) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from      edge  to        #>   <chr>     <chr> <chr>     #> 1 child_x1  -->   child_x2  #> 2 child_x2  -->   oldage_x5 #> 3 child_x2  -->   youth_x4  #> 4 oldage_x5 ---   oldage_x6 #> 5 youth_x3  -->   oldage_x5 #> 6 youth_x4  -->   oldage_x6 #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name      #>   <chr>     #> 1 child_x2  #> 2 child_x1  #> 3 youth_x4  #> 4 youth_x3  #> 5 oldage_x6 #> 6 oldage_x5 #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Tiers ── #>  #>   tier  #>   <chr> #> 1 child #> 2 youth #> 3 old   #> ── Variables ── #>  #>   var       tier  #>   <chr>     <chr> #> 1 child_x1  child #> 2 child_x2  child #> 3 youth_x3  youth #> 4 youth_x4  youth #> 5 oldage_x5 old   #> 6 oldage_x6 old    # Switch to TFCI on the same object (reuses suffStat/test) s_tpc$set_alg("tfci") res_tfci <- s_tpc$run_search() print(res_tfci) #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: UNKNOWN #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from      edge  to        #>   <chr>     <chr> <chr>     #> 1 child_x2  o-o   child_x1  #> 2 child_x2  o->   oldage_x5 #> 3 child_x2  o->   youth_x4  #> 4 oldage_x5 -->   oldage_x6 #> 5 youth_x3  o->   oldage_x5 #> 6 youth_x4  -->   oldage_x6 #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name      #>   <chr>     #> 1 child_x2  #> 2 child_x1  #> 3 youth_x4  #> 4 youth_x3  #> 5 oldage_x6 #> 6 oldage_x5 #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Tiers ── #>  #>   tier  #>   <chr> #> 1 child #> 2 youth #> 3 old   #> ── Variables ── #>  #>   var       tier  #>   <chr>     <chr> #> 1 child_x1  child #> 2 child_x2  child #> 3 youth_x3  youth #> 4 youth_x4  youth #> 5 oldage_x5 old   #> 6 oldage_x6 old    # --- Score-based: TGES -------------------------------------------------------- s_tges <- CausalDiscoSearch$new() s_tges$set_score("tbic") # Gaussian temporal score s_tges$set_alg("tges") s_tges$set_data(tpc_example, set_suff_stat = FALSE) # suff stat not used for TGES s_tges$set_knowledge(kn) res_tges <- s_tges$run_search() print(res_tges) #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from      edge  to        #>   <chr>     <chr> <chr>     #> 1 child_x1  ---   child_x2  #> 2 child_x2  -->   oldage_x5 #> 3 child_x2  -->   youth_x4  #> 4 oldage_x5 -->   oldage_x6 #> 5 youth_x3  -->   oldage_x5 #> 6 youth_x4  -->   oldage_x6 #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name      #>   <chr>     #> 1 child_x2  #> 2 child_x1  #> 3 youth_x4  #> 4 youth_x3  #> 5 oldage_x6 #> 6 oldage_x5 #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # --- Intentional error demonstrations ----------------------------------------  # run_search() without setting an algorithm try(CausalDiscoSearch$new()$run_search(tpc_example)) #> Error : Test must be set before sufficient statistic.  # set_suff_stat() requires data and test first s_err <- CausalDiscoSearch$new() try(s_err$set_suff_stat()) # no data & no test #> Error : Data must be set before sufficient statistic. s_err$set_data(tpc_example, set_suff_stat = FALSE) try(s_err$set_suff_stat()) # no test #> Error : Test must be set before sufficient statistic.  # unknown test / score / algorithm try(CausalDiscoSearch$new()$set_test("not_a_test")) #> Error : Unknown method: not_a_test try(CausalDiscoSearch$new()$set_score("not_a_score")) #> Error : Unknown score type using causalDisco engine: not_a_score try(CausalDiscoSearch$new()$set_alg("not_an_alg")) #> Error : Unknown method type using causalDisco engine: not_an_alg  # set_knowledge() requires a `knowledge` object try(CausalDiscoSearch$new()$set_knowledge(list(not = "knowledge"))) #> Error : Input must be a knowledge instance.

what: R6 Interface to pcalg Search Algorithms — PcalgSearch
title: R6 Interface to pcalg Search Algorithms — PcalgSearch
text: wrapper lets drive pcalg algorithms within causalDisco framework. arguments test, score, algorithm, see pcalg documentation, link respective sections .

title: R6 Interface to pcalg Search Algorithms — PcalgSearch
text: data data.frame holding data set currently attached search object. Can set set_data(). score function used build score, data set. Can set $set_score(). Recognized values : "sem_bic" - BIC score Gaussian observed data. See pcalg::GaussL0penObsScore. "sem_bic_int" - BIC score Gaussian data jointly interventional observational Gaussian data. See pcalg::GaussL0penIntScore. test function used test independence. Can set $set_test(). Recognized values : "fisher_z" - Fisher Z test Gaussian data. See pcalg::gaussCItest(). "g_square" - G square test discrete data. See pcalg::binCItest() pcalg::disCItest(). alg function used run search algorithm. Can set $set_alg(). Recognized values : "fci" - FCI algorithm. See fci() underlying pcalg::fci(). "ges" - GES algorithm. See ges() underlying pcalg::ges(). "pc" - PC algorithm. See pc() underlying pcalg::pc(). params list parameters test algorithm. Can set $set_params(). parameters passed test algorithm functions. suff_stat Sufficient statistic. format contents sufficient statistic depends test used. continuous Logical; whether sufficient statistic continuous test. continuous discrete TRUE, sufficient statistic build mixed test. discrete Logical; whether sufficient statistic discrete test. continuous discrete TRUE, sufficient statistic build mixed test. knowledge list fixed constraints search algorithm. Note, pcalg works symmetric knowledge. Thus, allowed types knowledge forbidden edges directions. adapt_df Logical; whether adapt degrees freedom discrete tests.

Recommended: my_pc <- pc(engine = "pcalg", test = "fisher_z") my_pc(num_data) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X1    ---   Z     #> 3 X2    ---   X3    #> 4 X2    -->   Y     #> 5 X3    -->   Y     #> 6 Z     -->   Y     #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # or disco(data = num_data, method = my_pc) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X1    ---   Z     #> 3 X2    ---   X3    #> 4 X2    -->   Y     #> 5 X3    -->   Y     #> 6 Z     -->   Y     #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # Example with detailed settings: my_pc2 <- pc(   engine = "pcalg",   test = "fisher_z",   alpha = 0.01,   m.max = 4,   skel.method = "original" )  disco(data = num_data, method = my_pc2) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X2    ---   X3    #> 3 X2    -->   Y     #> 4 X3    -->   Y     #> 5 Z     -->   X1    #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # With knowledge  kn <- knowledge(   num_data,   X1 %!-->% X2,   X2 %!-->% X1 )  disco(data = num_data, method = my_pc2, knowledge = kn) #>  #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from  edge  to    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    -->   Y     #> 2 X2    ---   X3    #> 3 X2    -->   Y     #> 4 X3    -->   Y     #> 5 Z     -->   X1    #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 X1    #> 2 X2    #> 3 X3    #> 4 Z     #> 5 Y     #> ── Knowledge object ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> ── Variables ── #>  #>   var   tier  #>   <chr> <chr> #> 1 X1    NA    #> 2 X2    NA    #> 3 X3    NA    #> 4 Y     NA    #> 5 Z     NA    #> ── Edges ── #>  #>  ✖  X1 → X2 #>  ✖  X2 → X1  # Using R6 class: s <- PcalgSearch$new()  s$set_test(method = "fisher_z", alpha = 0.05) s$set_data(tpc_example) s$set_alg("pc")  g <- s$run_search()  print(g) #> ── caugi graph ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Graph class: PDAG #>  #> ── Edges ── #>  #>   from      edge  to        #>   <chr>     <chr> <chr>     #> 1 child_x1  ---   child_x2  #> 2 child_x2  -->   oldage_x5 #> 3 child_x2  ---   youth_x4  #> 4 oldage_x5 -->   oldage_x6 #> 5 youth_x3  -->   oldage_x5 #> 6 youth_x4  -->   oldage_x6 #> ── Nodes ── #>  #>   name      #>   <chr>     #> 1 child_x2  #> 2 child_x1  #> 3 youth_x4  #> 4 youth_x3  #> 5 oldage_x6 #> 6 oldage_x5 #> ── Knowledge object ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

title: Temporal Bayesian Dirichlet equivalent uniform (Score criterion) — TemporalBDeu-class
text: Tobias Ellegaard Larsen

title: Temporal Bayesian Dirichlet equivalent uniform (Score criterion) — TemporalBDeu-class
code: # For reproducibility set.seed(1405)  # Number of samples n <- 1000  # Define probabilities for A p_A <- c(0.4, 0.35, 0.25) # Probabilities for A = {1, 2, 3}  # Simulate A from a categorical distribution A <- sample(1:3, n, replace = TRUE, prob = p_A)  # Define conditional probabilities for B given A p_B_given_A <- list(   c(0.7, 0.3), # P(B | A=1)   c(0.4, 0.6), # P(B | A=2)   c(0.2, 0.8) # P(B | A=3) )  # Sample B based on A B <- sapply(A, function(a) sample(1:2, 1, prob = p_B_given_A[[a]]))  # Define conditional probabilities for C given A and B p_C_given_A_B <- list(   "1_1" = c(0.6, 0.4), # P(C | A=1, B=1)   "1_2" = c(0.3, 0.7), # P(C | A=1, B=2)   "2_1" = c(0.5, 0.5), # P(C | A=2, B=1)   "2_2" = c(0.2, 0.8), # P(C | A=2, B=2)   "3_1" = c(0.7, 0.3), # P(C | A=3, B=1)   "3_2" = c(0.4, 0.6) # P(C | A=3, B=2) )  # Sample C based on A and B C <- mapply(   function(a, b) sample(1:2, 1, prob = p_C_given_A_B[[paste(a, b, sep = "_")]]),   A,   B )  # Create dataset simdata <- data.frame(as.factor(A), as.factor(B), as.factor(C))  # Define order in prefix way colnames(simdata) <- c("child_A", "child_B", "adult_C") prefix_order <- c("child", "adult")  # Define knowledge object kn <- knowledge(   simdata,   tier(     child ~ tidyselect::starts_with("child"),     adult ~ tidyselect::starts_with("adult")   ) )  # Define TemporalBDeu score t_score <- new("TemporalBDeu", knowledge = kn, data = simdata) # Run tges tges_pre <- tges_run(t_score)  # Plot MPDAG # plot(tges_pre)

title: Temporal Bayesian Information Criterion (Score criterion) — TemporalBIC-class
code: # Simulate Gaussian data set.seed(1405) n <- 500 child_x <- rnorm(n) child_y <- 0.5 * child_x + rnorm(n) child_z <- 2 * child_x + child_y + rnorm(n)  adult_x <- child_x + rnorm(n) adult_z <- child_z + rnorm(n) adult_w <- 2 * adult_z + rnorm(n) adult_y <- 2 * child_x + adult_w + rnorm(n)  simdata <- data.frame(   child_x,   child_y,   child_z,   adult_x,   adult_z,   adult_w,   adult_y )  # Define order in prefix way kn <- knowledge(   simdata,   tier(     child ~ tidyselect::starts_with("child"),     adult ~ tidyselect::starts_with("adult")   ) )  # Define TBIC score t_score <- new("TemporalBIC", knowledge = kn, data = simdata) # Run tges tges_pre <- tges_run(t_score)  # Plot MPDAG # plot(tges_pre)

what: R6 Interface to Tetrad Search Algorithms — TetradSearch
title: R6 Interface to Tetrad Search Algorithms — TetradSearch
text: High-level wrapper around Java-based Tetrad causal-discovery library. class lets choose independence tests, scores, search algorithms Tetrad, run R data set, retrieve resulting graph statistics.

title: R6 Interface to Tetrad Search Algorithms — TetradSearch
text: data Java object stores (possibly converted) data set used Tetrad. rdata Original R data.frame supplied user. score Java object holding scoring function selected set_score(). Supply one method strings set_score(). Recognised values : Continuous - Gaussian "ebic" - Extended BIC score. "gic" - Generalized Information Criterion (GIC) score. "poisson_prior" - Poisson prior score.' "rank_bic" - Rank-based BIC score. "sem_bic" - SEM BIC score. "zhang_shen_bound" - Zhang Shen bound score. Discrete - categorical "bdeu" - Bayes Dirichlet Equivalent score uniform priors. "discrete_bic" - BIC score discrete data. Mixed Discrete/Gaussian "basis_function_bic" - BIC score basis-function models. generalization Degenerate Gaussian score. "basis_function_blocks_bic" - BIC score mixed data using basis-function models. "basis_function_sem_bic" - SEM BIC score basis-function models. "conditional_gaussian" - Conditional Gaussian BIC score. "degenerate_gaussian" - Degenerate Gaussian BIC score. "mag_degenerate_gaussian_bic" - MAG Degenerate Gaussian BIC Score. test Java object holding independence test selected set_test(). Supply one method strings set_test(). Recognised values : Continuous - Gaussian "fisher_z" - Fisher \(Z\) (partial correlation) test. "poisson_prior" - Poisson prior test. "rank_independence" - Rank-based independence test. "sem_bic" - SEM BIC test. Discrete - categorical "chi_square" - chi-squared test "g_square" - likelihood-ratio \(G^2\) test. "probabilistic" - Uses BCInference Cooper Bui calculate probabilistic conditional independence judgments. General "gin" - Generalized Independence Noise test. "kci" - Kernel Conditional Independence Test (KCI) Kun Zhang. "rcit" - Randomized Conditional Independence Test (RCIT). Mixed Discrete/Gaussian "basis_function_blocks" - Basis-function blocks test. "basis_function_lrt" - basis-function likelihood-ratio. "conditional_gaussian" - Conditional Gaussian test likelihood ratio test. "degenerate_gaussian" - Degenerate Gaussian test likelihood ratio test. alg Java object representing search algorithm. Supply one method strings set_alg(). Recognised values : Constraint-based "fci" - FCI algorithm. See fci(). "pc" - Peter-Clark (PC) algorithm. See pc(). "rfci" - Restricted FCI algorithm. See pcalg::rfci(). Hybrid "boss_fci" - BOSS-FCI algorithm. See boss_fci(). "gfci" - GFCI algorithm. See gfci(). "grasp_fci" - GRaSP-FCI algorithm. See grasp_fci(). "sp_fci" - Sparsest Permutation using FCI. See sp_fci(). Score-based "boss" - BOSS algorithm. See boss(). "ges" ("fges") - (Fast) Greedy Equivalence Search (GES) algorithm. See ges(). "grasp" - GRaSP (Greedy Relations Sparsest Permutation) algorithm. See grasp(). mc_test Java independence-test object used Markov checker. java Java object returned search (typically graph). result Convenience alias java; may store additional metadata depending search type. knowledge Java Knowledge object carrying background constraints (required/forbidden edges). params Java Parameters object holding algorithm settings. bootstrap_graphs Java List graphs produced bootstrap resampling, feature requested. mc_ind_results Java List Markov-checker test results.

title: R6 Interface to Tetrad Search Algorithms — TetradSearch
R6 Interface to Tetrad Search Algorithms — TetradSearch
text: method (character) Name test method (e.g., "chi_square", "fisher_z"). "basis_function_blocks" - Basis-function blocks test "basis_function_lrt" - basis-function likelihood-ratio "chi_square" - chi-squared test "conditional_gaussian" - Mixed discrete/continuous test "degenerate_gaussian" - Degenerate Gaussian test likelihood ratio test "fisher_z" - Fisher \(Z\) (partial correlation) test "gin" - Generalized Independence Noise test "kci" - Kernel Conditional Independence Test (KCI) Kun Zhang "poisson_prior" - Poisson prior test "probabilistic" - Uses BCInference Cooper Bui calculate probabilistic conditional independence judgments. "rcit" - Randomized Conditional Independence Test (RCIT) "rank_independence" - Rank-based independence test "sem_bic" - SEM BIC test ... Additional arguments passed private test-setting methods. following tests, following parameters available: "basis_function_blocks" - Basis-function blocks test. alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, basis_type = "polynomial" - type basis use. Supported types "polynomial", "legendre", "hermite", "chebyshev", truncation_limit = 3 - Basis functions 1 number used. Degenerate Gaussian category indicator variables mixed data also used. "basis_function_lrt" - basis-function likelihood-ratio truncation_limit = 3 - Basis functions 1 number used. Degenerate Gaussian category indicator variables mixed data also used, alpha = 0.05 - Significance level likelihood-ratio test, singularity_lambda = 0.0 - Small number >= 0: Add lambda diagonal, < 0 Pseudoinverse, do_one_equation_only = FALSE - TRUE, one equation used expanding basis. "chi_square" - chi-squared test min_count = 1 - Minimum count chi-squared test per cell. Increasing can improve accuracy test estimates, alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, cell_table_type = "ad" - type cell table use optimization. Available types : "ad" - AD tree, "count" - Count sample. "conditional_gaussian" - Mixed discrete/continuous test alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, discretize = TRUE - TRUE conditional Gaussian likelihood, scoring X –> D X continuous D discrete, one simply discretize X just cases. FALSE, integration exact, num_categories_to_discretize = 3 - case exact algorithm used discrete children continuous parents used, parameter gives number categories use second (discretized) backup copy continuous variables, min_sample_size_per_cell = 4 - Minimum sample size per cell independence test. "degenerate_gaussian" - Degenerate Gaussian likelihood ratio test alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, singularity_lambda = 0.0 - Small number >= 0: Add lambda diagonal, < 0 Pseudoinverse. "fisher_z" - Fisher \(Z\) (partial correlation) test alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, singularity_lambda = 0.0 - Small number >= 0: Add lambda diagonal, < 0 Pseudoinverse. "gin" - Generalized Independence Noise test. alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, gin_backend = "dcor" - Unconditional test residual independence. Available types "dcor" - Distance correlation (non-linear) "pearson" - Pearson correlation (linear), num_permutations = 200 - Number permutations used "dcor" backend. "pearson" backend used, parameter ignored. gin_ridge = 1e-8 - Ridge parameter used computing residuals. small number >= 0. seed = -1 - Random seed independence test. -1, seed set. "kci" - Kernel Conditional Independence Test (KCI) Kun Zhang alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, approximate = TRUE - TRUE, use approximate Gamma approximation algorithm. FALSE, use exact, scaling_factor = 1 - Gaussian kernel: scaling factor * Silverman bandwidth. num_bootstraps = 1000 - Number bootstrap samples use KCI test. used approximate = FALSE. threshold = 1e-3 - Threshold KCI test. Threshold determine many eigenvalues use – lower (0 1). kernel_type = "gaussian" - type kernel use. Available types "gaussian", "linear", "polynomial". polyd = 5 - degree polynomial kernel, used. polyc = 1 - constant polynomial kernel, used. "poisson_prior" - Poisson prior test poisson_lambda = 1 - Lambda parameter Poisson distribution (> 0), singularity_lambda = 0.0 - Small number >= 0: Add lambda diagonal, < 0 Pseudoinverse. "probabilistic" - Uses BCInference Cooper Bui calculate probabilistic conditional independence judgments. threshold = FALSE - Set TRUE using cutoff threshold independence test, cutoff = 0.5 - Cutoff independence test, prior_ess = 10 - Prior equivalent sample size independence test. number added sample size conditional probability table model divided equally among cells table. "rcit" - Randomized Conditional Independence Test (RCIT). alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test, rcit_approx = "lpb4" - Null approximation method. Recognized values : "lpb4" - Lindsay-Pilla-Basak method 4 support points, "hbe" - Hall-Buckley-Eagleson method, "gamma" - Gamma (Satterthwaite-Welch), "chi_square" - Chi-square (normalized), "permutation" - Permutation-based (computationally intensive), rcit_ridge = 1e-3 - Ridge parameter used computing residuals. small number >= 0, num_feat = 10 - Number random features use regression X Y Z. Values 5 20 often suffice. num_fourier_feat_xy = 5 - Number random Fourier features use tested variables X Y. Small values often suffice (e.g., 3 10), num_fourier_feat_z = 100 - Number random Fourier features use conditioning set Z. Values 50 300 often suffice, center_features = TRUE - TRUE, center random features mean zero. Recommended better numerical stability, use_rcit = TRUE - TRUE, use RCIT; FALSE, use RCoT (Randomized Conditional Correlation Test), num_permutations = 500 - Number permutations used independence test rcit_approx = "permutation" selected. seed = -1 - Random seed independence test. -1, seed set. "rank_independence" - Rank-based independence test. alpha = 0.05 - Significance level independence test. "sem_bic" - SEM BIC test. penalty_discount = 2 - Penalty discount factor used BIC = 2L - ck log N, c penalty. Higher c yield sparser graphs, structure_prior = 0 - default number parents conditional probability table. Higher weight accorded tables number parents. prior structure weights distributed according binomial distribution, singularity_lambda = 0.0 - Small number >= 0: Add lambda diagonal, < 0 Pseudoinverse. use_for_mc (logical) TRUE, sets test Markov checker mc_test.
